Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Improving the Length and Consistency of a Biomimetic Silk Fiber for Industrial Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite its promise, the full benefits of spider silk have yet to be harnessed as all previous spinning techniques have resulted in inferior synthetic fibers. While the natural underlying chemical structure and fiber production of spider silks have co-evolved over millions of years, synthetic silk fiber production devices do not mimic the biological process and are plagued by inconsistency because of (1) a simplified spinning process, and (2) shorter and incomplete protein/polymers used in spinning. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award will support the generation of data to demonstrate the feasibility of mimicking the natural silk spinning process using additive manufacturing to produce consistent, high-performance, silk-based fibers of length. This award will enable fundamental research to provide needed knowledge for the commercial development of spider silk and other high performance micron-scale fibers. The new process will enable predictable diameter silk fibers for use in automotive, military, biomedical, and other commercial endeavors to be produced via shear thinning. Therefore, results from this research will benefit the U.S. economy and society. This research involves several disciplines including mechanical engineering, cell and molecular biology, control theory, and materials science and will help broaden participation of underrepresented groups, integrating multiple students in research and positively impacting engineering education.

Although major ampullate spider silk has been sought after for its characteristic strength and toughness for decades, production of the fiber has been hampered by inconsistency. Recently, new knowledge about the spider's black box silk production has been obtained, providing important insight into high-performance fiber production. A combination of chemical environment and mechanical forces are necessary to produce high-performance, micron-scale fibers. Previous efforts have not provided this combination and have produced fibers with inferior mechanical properties. The advent of additive manufacturing and microfluidics will allow both the shear forces as well as the chemical environment (i.e., pH or ionic gradient) of the spider's biological silk spinning system to be mimicked, representing a significant departure from the current dogma of the field. This research will establish a predictable correlation between the genetic sequence of the protein, the chemical environment of the spin dope, and the mechanical shear necessary for protein polymerization and silk production. The research team will produce (1) an immortalized spider silk gland cell line as a steady source of silk proteins, (2) micron-sized silk fibers with consistent diameter, (3) mechanically-tailored and predictable fibers based on alterations of mechanical shear.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

This RESEARCH project was focused on developing tools to produce consistent, synthetic-spun, high-performance spider silk fibers. Two key constraints limit the ability of researchers to reach this goal: (1) the inability to artificially produce and purify full-length, natural spider silk proteins and (2) the inability to recreate an environment that captures the properties of the natural spinning process to provide consistency over the length of a fiber. Here, we proposed to address these issues by culturing major ampullate spider-silk gland cells that secrete full-length, natural major ampullate spider silk proteins and by designing a 3D printed microfluidic device that mimics the native environment of the spider’s spinning system. Recent innovations in additive manufacturing and genome engineering (cell immortalization and CRISPR) allow us to take a fresh approach to this problem. During the period of this award, we have been able to design and produce a microfluidic spider silk spinning system capable of mimicking conditions within the spider’s silk gland.  Using the principles of fluid flow, we have been able to use shear forces to produce a synthetic fiber with approximately the same dimensions as natural silk fibers.  This has also given us insight into how silk protein assembles to form aggregates and fibers.  Despite this technology, the commercial potential of spider silk may still not be realized due to limitations in the raw material (i.e., silk protein) for the system.  Therefore, we have isolated the cells that line the spider’s major ampullate silk gland and secrete full-length silk protein.  Although others are working toward high performance synthetic spider silk production, their solutions, which are focused either on biological alterations or physical engineering aspects, represent a woefully simplified solution to solve a complex problem and are unable to provide consistent fibers of length.  Finally, we have taken an engineering/machine learning approach to optimize the culturing of cells and production of major ampullate silk protein.

Broader Impacts:

Due to its high-tensile strength and elasticity, the variety of applications spawned from this spider silk is exciting and almost endless.  Unfortunately, despite decades of study, the promise of spider silk has yet to be fulfilled.  Although the underlying molecular structure/function relationships that govern spider silk fibers are well defined and the methods to manipulate and engineer those relationships now relatively routine, current efforts that focus on mimicking simplified sections of spider silk proteins are of limited value. Coupled with simplified spinning systems that built on the same mechanics as dispensing toothpaste, instead of the more complex and controlled mechanics of the spider, which at a rudimentary level can be thought of as analogous to pulling floss, use of these smaller, synthetic proteins has led to mechanically inferior and unusable fibers. Producing tailored, application-specific fibers for a wide variety of applications requires rethinking both the protein raw material for the fiber as well as the material processing of the protein.  Therefore, during the course of this project, we have synthesized the body of knowledge regarding the structure, chemistry, and biology of the major ampullate silk gland of the golden orb weaver to develop both cell culture conditions and a spinning system to probe the underlying biological complexity of the spider. Ultimately, using these new insights, we have been able to spin silk fibers with tailored diameters, and associated mechanical performance, from natural spider silk proteins.  With these new tools in hand, hopefully, we can begin to realize the promise of spider silk in commercial, biomedical, and military applications.

 


Last Modified: 02/01/2020
Modified by: Amanda Brooks
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Intellectual Merit: This RESEARCH project was focused on developing tools to produce consistent, synthetic-spun, high-performance spider silk fibers. Two key constraints limit the ability of researchers to reach this goal: (1) the inability to artificially produce and purify full-length, natural spider silk proteins and (2) the inability to recreate an environment that captures the properties of the natural spinning process to provide consistency over the length of a fiber. Here, we proposed to address these issues by culturing major ampullate spider-silk gland cells that secrete full-length, natural major ampullate spider silk proteins and by designing a 3D printed microfluidic device that mimics the native environment of the spider’s spinning system. Recent innovations in additive manufacturing and genome engineering (cell immortalization and CRISPR) allow us to take a fresh approach to this problem. During the period of this award, we have been able to design and produce a microfluidic spider silk spinning system capable of mimicking conditions within the spider’s silk gland. Using the principles of fluid flow, we have been able to use shear forces to produce a synthetic fiber with approximately the same dimensions as natural silk fibers. This has also given us insight into how silk protein assembles to form aggregates and fibers. Despite this technology, the commercial potential of spider silk may still not be realized due to limitations in the raw material (i.e., silk protein) for the system. Therefore, we have isolated the cells that line the spider’s major ampullate silk gland and secrete full-length silk protein. Although others are working toward high performance synthetic spider silk production, their solutions, which are focused either on biological alterations or physical engineering aspects, represent a woefully simplified solution to solve a complex problem and are unable to provide consistent fibers of length. Finally, we have taken an engineering/machine learning approach to optimize the culturing of cells and production of major ampullate silk protein. Broader Impacts: Due to its high-tensile strength and elasticity, the variety of applications spawned from this spider silk is exciting and almost endless. Unfortunately, despite decades of study, the promise of spider silk has yet to be fulfilled. Although the underlying molecular structure/function relationships that govern spider silk fibers are well defined and the methods to manipulate and engineer those relationships now relatively routine, current efforts that focus on mimicking simplified sections of spider silk proteins are of limited value. Coupled with simplified spinning systems that built on the same mechanics as dispensing toothpaste, instead of the more complex and controlled mechanics of the spider, which at a rudimentary level can be thought of as analogous to pulling floss, use of these smaller, synthetic proteins has led to mechanically inferior and unusable fibers. Producing tailored, application-specific fibers for a wide variety of applications requires rethinking both the protein raw material for the fiber as well as the material processing of the protein. Therefore, during the course of this project, we have synthesized the body of knowledge regarding the structure, chemistry, and biology of the major ampullate silk gland of the golden orb weaver to develop both cell culture conditions and a spinning system to probe the underlying biological complexity of the spider. Ultimately, using these new insights, we have been able to spin silk fibers with tailored diameters, and associated mechanical performance, from natural spider silk proteins. With these new tools in hand, hopefully, we can begin to realize the promise of spider silk in commercial, biomedical, and military applications.
